html:
Etymology 1[edit]

From levis (“light, not heavy”).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈle.wi.ɡoː/, [ˈlɛ.wɪ.ɡoː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈle.vi.ɡo/, [ˈlɛː.vi.ɡɔ]

Verb[edit]

levigō (present infinitive levigāre, perfect active levigāvī, supine levigātum); first conjugation

  1. I make light, lighten
Conjugation[edit]

Synonyms[edit]
  • (make light, lighten): levō
Related terms[edit]
  • levāmentum

  • levis
  • levitās
  • leviter
  • levō

Etymology 2[edit]

From lēvis (“smooth”).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈleː.wi.ɡoː/, [ˈleː.wɪ.ɡoː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈle.vi.ɡo/, [ˈlɛː.vi.ɡɔ]

Verb[edit]

lēvigō (present infinitive lēvigāre, perfect active lēvigāvī, supine lēvigātum); first conjugation

  1. I make smooth, polish
Conjugation[edit]

Descendants[edit]
  • Catalan: levigar
  • English: levigate
  • French: léviger
  • Italian: levigare
  • Spanish: levigar

References[edit]

  • levigo in Charlton T. Lewis and Charles Short (1879) A Latin Dictionary, Oxford: Clarendon Press
  • levigo in Gaffiot, Félix (1934) Dictionnaire Illustré Latin-Français, Hachette
